tool.name: Multiple Testing Adjustment (MTA)

param.name: input
param.label: Wide Dataset
param.help: Input dataset in wide format and tab separated. If not tab separated see TIP below.

param.name: uniqID
param.label: Unique Feature ID
param.help: Name of the column in your Wide Dataset that has unique Feature IDs.

param.name: pval
param.label: p-value column
param.help: Name of the column in your Wide Dataset that has your pvalue.

param.name: alpha
param.label: α
param.help: Value of α to be used on the corrections by default α=0.05.

tool.help:
@TIP_AND_WARNING@
**Tool Description**
The tool is designed to adjust the column of -values for multiple comparison using three different methods. Bonferroni method is used together with two false discovery rate (FDR) methods: Benjamini-Hochberg method (BH) and Benjamini-Yekutieli method (BY). The adjustment can be performed for the column outputs from Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) Fixed Effects Model Tool. The user also has an option to upload wide dataset with the column of -values. User can control total type I error α. More details about the PH and BY methods are available in the papers: Benjamini, Y., and Hochberg, Y. (1995). Controlling the false discovery rate: a practical and powerful approach to multiple testing. Journal of the royal statistical society. Series B (Methodological), 289-300. Benjamini, Y., and Yekutieli, D. (2001). The control of the false discovery rate in multiple testing under dependency. Annals of statistics, 1165-1188.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
**Input**
- Two input datasets are required.
@WIDE@
@UNIQID@
**Name for p-value column**
- Name of the column in your Wide Dataset that has your pvalue.
**α**
- Value of α to be used on the corrections by default α=0.05.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
**Output**
The tool produces two TSV files,the first one is for the corrected p-values that contains five columns: the first one is the column with unique feature IDs, the second one is the column of the original p-values and the last three contain adjusted p-values. Every column of p-values corresponds to different adjustment method, which is reflected in the column name. The second file is a TSV file containing flags where all the values that did not pass the alpha value are flagged as 1.
